1.name: Frontal Pole (BA 10)
structure: Most anterior portion of the frontal lobe
Rich in granular cells with prominent layer IV
High proportion of dendritic spines
Extensive connections with prefrontal association areas, limbic structures, and anterior thalamic nuclei
function: Involved in higher cognitive functions including working memory and executive functions
Plays a key role in prospective memory and multitasking
Participates in cognitive branching and integration of outcomes from multiple cognitive operations
Associated with metacognition, insight, and introspection

2.name: Insular Cortex
structure: Located deep within the lateral sulcus, covered by frontal, parietal, and temporal opercula
Divided into anterior (agranular) and posterior (granular) portions
Rich in von Economo neurons in the anterior division
Connected to limbic structures, thalamus, basal ganglia, and multiple cortical regions
function: Integrates interoceptive information including visceral sensation, pain, temperature, and taste
Contributes to emotional processing and empathy
Involved in salience detection and attentional switching
Participates in autonomic regulation and visceromotor control

3.name: Superior Frontal Gyrus (BA 8, 9)
structure: Located in the dorsolateral and medial surfaces of the frontal lobe
Extends from the precentral gyrus to the frontal pole
Posterior portion contains the frontal eye field (BA 8)
Connected extensively with prefrontal and premotor regions, and thalamic nuclei
function: Participates in higher cognitive functions including working memory and executive control
Frontal eye field portion controls voluntary eye movements and visual attention
Involved in spatial cognition and self-awareness
Contributes to planning complex movements and response inhibition

4.name: Middle Frontal Gyrus (BA 9, 46)
structure: Located between superior and inferior frontal sulci
Contains the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC)
Rich in pyramidal cells with extensive dendritic arborization
Connected with multiple association areas, thalamus, and striatum
function: Critical for working memory maintenance and manipulation
Essential for cognitive flexibility and task switching
Involved in abstract reasoning and problem-solving
Participates in decision-making and goal-directed behavior

5.name: Inferior Frontal Gyrus, pars triangularis (BA 45)
structure: Forms part of Broca's area in the dominant (usually left) hemisphere
Triangular-shaped region bounded by anterior ascending and horizontal rami of the lateral sulcus
Contains high density of language-related neural circuits
Connected to other language areas via the arcuate fasciculus and superior longitudinal fasciculus
function: Critical component of the expressive language network
Involved in semantic processing and word retrieval
Participates in syntax processing and grammatical operations
When damaged in the dominant hemisphere, contributes to Broca's aphasia

6.name: Inferior Frontal Gyrus, pars opercularis (BA 44)
structure: Posterior component of Broca's area in the dominant hemisphere
Located between precentral sulcus and vertical ramus of lateral sulcus
Contains mirror neurons in humans
Connected to premotor cortex, arcuate fasciculus, and superior longitudinal fasciculus
function: Critical for speech production and articulatory planning
Involved in phonological processing and working memory
Participates in action observation and imitation
Damage results in effortful speech with preserved comprehension in Broca's aphasia

7.name: Precentral Gyrus (BA 4, 6)
structure: Primary motor cortex (BA 4) and premotor cortex (BA 6)
Located anterior to central sulcus
Contains giant pyramidal Betz cells in layer V of BA 4
Organized somatotopically as motor homunculus (legs superior, face inferior)
function: Execution of voluntary movement through direct projections to spinal motor neurons
Premotor regions involved in movement planning and preparation
Encodes parameters of movement including direction, force, and velocity
Damage results in contralateral hemiparesis with upper motor neuron signs

8.name: Temporal Pole (BA 38)
structure: Most anterior portion of temporal lobe
Transitional cortex between neocortex and allocortex
Rich connections with limbic structures including amygdala and orbitofrontal cortex
Part of the anterior temporal lobe network
function: Integration of complex, highly processed perceptual inputs with emotional responses
Involved in social-emotional processing including theory of mind
Contributes to semantic memory for unique entities
Associated with personal semantic memory and autobiographical memory

9.name: Superior Temporal Gyrus, anterior division (BA 22, 38)
structure: Anterior portion of the superior temporal gyrus
Bordered medially by the lateral sulcus and inferiorly by superior temporal sulcus
Contains auditory association cortex
Connected to primary auditory cortex, inferior frontal gyrus, and limbic structures
function: Processes complex auditory stimuli including speech and voice recognition
Contributes to language comprehension in the dominant hemisphere
Involved in social cognition through voice prosody analysis
Participates in auditory working memory

10.name: Superior Temporal Gyrus, posterior division (BA 22)
structure: Posterior portion of superior temporal gyrus
Contains Wernicke's area in the dominant hemisphere
Adjacent to temporoparietal junction
Connected to arcuate fasciculus, angular gyrus, and other language areas
function: Critical for auditory language comprehension in dominant hemisphere
Involved in phonological processing and speech perception
Participates in integration of auditory and visual information
Damage to this area in dominant hemisphere can result in Wernicke's aphasia

11.name: Middle Temporal Gyrus, anterior division (BA 21)
structure: Anterior portion of middle temporal gyrus
Located between superior and inferior temporal sulci
Association cortex with columnar organization
Connected to temporal pole, superior temporal gyrus, and ventral processing stream
function: Involved in semantic processing of language
Contributes to multimodal integration of sensory information
Participates in conceptual knowledge representation
Associated with processing of contextual associations

12.name: Middle Temporal Gyrus, posterior division (BA 21, 37)
structure: Posterior portion of middle temporal gyrus
Located at the interface of temporal and parietal lobes
Higher-order association cortex
Connected to dorsal and ventral processing streams
function: Involved in lexical-semantic processing
Contributes to audiovisual integration
Participates in tool recognition and action understanding
Associated with processing of biological motion

13.name: Middle Temporal Gyrus, temporooccipital part (BA 37, 39)
structure: Junction between temporal and occipital lobes
Part of the ventral visual processing stream
Association cortex with connections to visual and language areas
Connected to inferior temporal gyrus and angular gyrus
function: Involved in visual word form recognition
Contributes to semantic processing of visual stimuli
Participates in object recognition and naming
Associated with cross-modal integration of visual and linguistic information

14.name: Inferior Temporal Gyrus, anterior division (BA 20)
structure: Anterior portion of the inferior temporal gyrus
Located lateral to the fusiform gyrus, inferior to the middle temporal gyrus
Part of the ventral visual processing stream
Connected to temporal pole and other temporal lobe structures
function: Involved in complex visual processing and object recognition
Contributes to visual semantics and conceptual knowledge
Participates in face recognition
Associated with lexical-semantic processing for concrete concepts

15.name: Inferior Temporal Gyrus, posterior division (BA 20, 37)
structure: Posterior portion of inferior temporal gyrus
Higher-order visual association cortex
Part of the ventral visual stream
Connected to middle temporal and fusiform gyri
function: Involved in high-level visual processing and object recognition
Contributes to visual categorization and identification
Participates in reading and visual word form processing
Associated with visual-semantic integration

16.name: Inferior Temporal Gyrus, temporooccipital part (BA 37)
structure: Junction between inferior temporal gyrus and occipital lobe
Part of the ventral visual stream
Connected to visual areas and language networks
Adjacent to lateral occipital complex
function: Involved in high-level visual object recognition
Contributes to reading and visual word form processing
Participates in naming and categorization of visual stimuli
Associated with visual semantics and memory

17.name: Postcentral Gyrus (BA 1, 2, 3)
structure: Primary somatosensory cortex located posterior to central sulcus
Organized somatotopically as sensory homunculus
BA 3 (anterior) receives thalamocortical projections, BA 1 and 2 (posterior) are higher-order
Connected to thalamus via thalamocortical radiations and to motor cortex
function: Processes tactile sensation, proprioception, and haptic information
Discriminates touch, pressure, vibration, and joint position
Maps the contralateral body with disproportionate representation of hands and face
Damage results in contralateral sensory loss and astereognosis

18.name: Superior Parietal Lobule (BA 5, 7)
structure: Located posterior to postcentral gyrus and superior to intraparietal sulcus
Higher-order association cortex
Connected to dorsal visual stream and sensorimotor areas
Rich in neurons that integrate multimodal sensory information
function: Integrates somatosensory and visual information for spatial processing
Involved in visuomotor coordination and reaching movements
Contributes to spatial attention and mental rotation
Damage may result in optic ataxia and deficits in visual guidance of movement

19.name: Supramarginal Gyrus, anterior division (BA 40)
structure: Anterior portion of the supramarginal gyrus
Part of the inferior parietal lobule
Arches around the posterior end of the lateral sulcus
Connected to sensorimotor areas and arcuate fasciculus
function: Involved in processing of somatosensory information and phonological working memory
Contributes to tactile object recognition and tool use
Participates in phonological aspects of language processing
Damage to left hemisphere may contribute to conduction aphasia and ideomotor apraxia

20.name: Supramarginal Gyrus, posterior division (BA 40)
structure: Posterior portion of supramarginal gyrus
Part of the inferior parietal lobule
Connected to superior temporal and angular gyri
Part of the ventral attention network
function: Involved in spatial attention and awareness
Contributes to phonological processing and working memory
Participates in gesture recognition and production
Right hemisphere damage associated with neglect syndrome

21.name: Angular Gyrus (BA 39)
structure: Located at the posterior part of inferior parietal lobule
Surrounds the ascending portion of superior temporal sulcus
Multimodal association cortex at the junction of temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes
Connected to language, visual, and attention networks
function: Critical for reading comprehension and semantic processing
Involved in number processing and calculation
Contributes to verbal working memory and theory of mind
Damage to left angular gyrus may result in Gerstmann syndrome

22.name: Lateral Occipital Cortex, superior division (BA 19)
structure: Superior portion of lateral occipital cortex
Higher-order visual association area
Part of the dorsal visual stream ('where' pathway)
Connected to V1, V2, and parietal visual areas
function: Processes global form perception and spatial relationships
Involved in motion perception and visual spatial attention
Contributes to object recognition based on shape
Participates in visually guided actions

23.name: Lateral Occipital Cortex, inferior division (BA 18, 19)
structure: Inferior portion of lateral occipital cortex
Part of the ventral visual stream ('what' pathway)
Higher-order visual association area
Connected to primary visual cortex and temporal visual areas
function: Critical for object recognition and visual form processing
Contains the lateral occipital complex (LOC) which responds to object shapes
Involved in figure-ground segregation
Contributes to visual working memory

24.name: Intracalcarine Cortex (BA 17)
structure: Primary visual cortex (V1) located within the calcarine sulcus
Striate cortex with distinctive line of Gennari in layer IV
Retinotopically organized with posterior portions representing central vision
Receives direct projections from lateral geniculate nucleus of thalamus
function: Initial cortical processing of visual information
Detects basic visual features including orientation, spatial frequency, and color
Provides hierarchical input to higher visual areas
Damage results in contralateral visual field defects

25.name: Frontal Medial Cortex (BA 10, 32)
structure: Located on the medial surface of the frontal lobe
Includes portions of medial prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate
Rich in connections with limbic structures and other prefrontal regions
Part of the default mode network
function: Involved in social cognition and theory of mind
Contributes to self-referential processing and introspection
Participates in value-based decision making
Associated with emotion regulation and mentalization

26.name: Juxtapositional Lobule Cortex (Supplementary Motor Area, BA 6)
structure: Located on medial surface of frontal lobe anterior to paracentral lobule
Contains supplementary motor area (SMA) and pre-SMA
Connected to primary motor cortex, basal ganglia, and spinal cord
Somatotopically organized but less distinctly than primary motor cortex
function: Critical for motor planning and initiation of voluntary movements
Involved in sequential movement programming and bimanual coordination
Contributes to speech motor planning
Damage can result in alien hand syndrome and akinesia

27.name: Subcallosal Cortex (BA 25)
structure: Located below the genu of corpus callosum
Part of the subgenual cingulate region
Connected to hypothalamus, amygdala, and other limbic structures
Contains portions of septal nuclei and ventral striatum
function: Key node in the limbic system involved in emotion processing
Implicated in mood regulation and autonomic response to emotional stimuli
Target for deep brain stimulation in treatment-resistant depression
Participates in reward processing and motivation

28.name: Paracingulate Gyrus (BA 32)
structure: Located dorsal to the cingulate gyrus on the medial surface
Present variably with left hemisphere predominance
Connected to dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate
Part of the cognitive control network
function: Involved in cognitive control and performance monitoring
Contributes to conflict resolution and error detection
Participates in action selection and inhibition
Associated with theory of mind and social cognition

29.name: Cingulate Gyrus, anterior division (BA 24, 32)
structure: Located above corpus callosum in the medial frontal lobe
Part of the limbic system with agranular/dysgranular cortex
Connected to prefrontal cortex, insula, and subcortical structures
Contains spindle-shaped von Economo neurons
function: Involved in cognitive control, error detection, and conflict monitoring
Participates in attention regulation and task engagement
Contributes to autonomic control and emotional processing
Associated with motivation and reward-based decision making

30.name: Cingulate Gyrus, posterior division (BA 23, 31)
structure: Posterior portion of cingulate gyrus above corpus callosum
Connected to parietal cortex, parahippocampal regions, and anterior cingulate
Part of the default mode network
Contains transition from limbic to higher-order association cortex
function: Involved in spatial memory and navigation
Contributes to autobiographical memory retrieval
Participates in self-reflection and internal mentation
Associated with assessment of personal significance of events

31.name: Precuneous Cortex (BA 7, 31)
structure: Located on the medial surface of the parietal lobe anterior to occipital lobe
Higher-order association cortex with complex columnar organization
Connected to posterior cingulate, lateral parietal cortex, and visual areas
Key hub of the default mode network
function: Involved in episodic memory retrieval and self-processing
Contributes to visuospatial processing and mental imagery
Participates in consciousness and self-awareness
Associated with theory of mind and perspective taking

32.name: Cuneal Cortex (BA 17, 18, 19)
structure: Located on the medial surface of the occipital lobe above calcarine sulcus
Contains portions of primary (BA 17) and secondary (BA 18, 19) visual cortex
Retinotopically organized representing superior visual field
Connected to lateral geniculate nucleus and higher visual areas
function: Processes visual information from the inferior visual field
Contributes to basic visual feature detection
Participates in visual attention and awareness
Damage results in inferior quadrantanopia

33.name: Frontal Orbital Cortex (BA 11, 47)
structure: Located on the orbital surface of the frontal lobe
Includes lateral and medial orbitofrontal regions
Connected to limbic structures, insula, and other prefrontal regions
Rich in connections with olfactory system and gustatory cortex
function: Critical for reward processing and value-based decision making
Involved in response inhibition and behavioral regulation
Contributes to emotional processing and social cognition
Associated with olfactory and gustatory processing

34.name: Parahippocampal Gyrus, anterior division (BA 28, 34, 35)
structure: Anterior portion of parahippocampal gyrus including entorhinal cortex
Transitional cortex between neocortex and allocortex
Major input to hippocampus via perforant pathway
Connected to amygdala, hippocampus, and association cortices
function: Critical for memory encoding and consolidation
Processes contextual information for episodic memory
Contributes to spatial navigation via grid cells
Early site of pathology in Alzheimer's disease

35.name: Parahippocampal Gyrus, posterior division (BA 27, 36)
structure: Posterior portion of parahippocampal gyrus including parahippocampal cortex
Connected to hippocampus, visual association areas, and retrosplenial cortex
Part of the medial temporal lobe memory system
Contains parahippocampal place area
function: Involved in processing spatial context and scenes
Contributes to episodic memory encoding and retrieval
Participates in navigation and spatial orientation
Damage associated with topographical disorientation

36.name: Lingual Gyrus (BA 17, 18, 19)
structure: Located on the medial surface of the occipital lobe below calcarine sulcus
Contains portions of primary (V1) and secondary (V2, V3) visual cortex
Retinotopically organized representing superior visual field
Connected to visual processing streams and parahippocampal gyrus
function: Processes visual information from the superior visual field
Involved in color processing and visual recognition
Contributes to visual memory and dream imagery
Damage may result in superior quadrantanopia

37.name: Temporal Fusiform Cortex, anterior division (BA 20, 36)
structure: Anterior portion of fusiform gyrus on the ventral surface of temporal lobe
Connected to anterior temporal lobe, amygdala, and ventral visual stream
Part of the ventral visual pathway
Association cortex with complex columnar organization
function: Involved in processing of high-level visual concepts
Contributes to semantic memory and concept formation
Participates in face and object recognition
Associated with processing socially relevant visual stimuli

38.name: Temporal Fusiform Cortex, posterior division (BA 37)
structure: Posterior portion of fusiform gyrus on ventral temporal surface
Contains the fusiform face area (FFA) and visual word form area (VWFA)
Higher-order visual association cortex
Connected to early visual areas and anterior temporal lobe
function: Specialized for face processing in fusiform face area
Critical for visual word recognition in visual word form area
Contributes to object recognition and categorization
Associated with color processing and synesthetic experiences

39.name: Temporal Occipital Fusiform Cortex (BA 37)
structure: Junction between temporal and occipital portions of fusiform gyrus
Higher-order visual association cortex
Part of the ventral visual stream
Connected to early visual areas and inferior temporal regions
function: Involved in object recognition and visual categorization
Contributes to reading and visual word form processing
Participates in face perception
Specialized for recognizing specific visual categories (e.g., places, bodies)

40.name: Occipital Fusiform Gyrus (BA 18, 19)
structure: Posterior portion of fusiform gyrus in the occipital lobe
Secondary and tertiary visual cortex
Part of the ventral visual stream
Connected to primary visual cortex and temporal fusiform regions
function: Early stages of object recognition and form processing
Involved in color perception and visual feature integration
Contributes to figure-ground segregation
Participates in visual attention to objects

41.name: Frontal Operculum Cortex (BA 44, 45, 47)
structure: Inferior frontal lobe region covering insula
Includes portions of inferior frontal gyrus
Connected to insular cortex, ventral premotor cortex, and language areas
Part of the ventral language stream
function: Involved in language processing particularly phonological and syntactic aspects
Contributes to response inhibition and executive control
Participates in working memory operations
Associated with processing of hierarchical structures in language and music

42.name: Central Opercular Cortex (BA 43, 6, 4)
structure: Located at the junction of frontal, parietal, and temporal opercula
Covers portion of insula adjacent to central sulcus
Connected to primary sensorimotor areas and insula
Contains representations of face, mouth, and tongue
function: Involved in sensorimotor processing of orofacial movements
Contributes to speech articulation and phonation
Participates in gustatory processing
Associated with oral tactile sensation

43.name: Parietal Operculum Cortex (BA 40, 43)
structure: Inferior parietal lobe region covering posterior insula
Contains secondary somatosensory cortex (S2)
Connected to primary somatosensory cortex, insula, and thalamus
Receives projections from both ipsilateral and contralateral body
function: Processes complex somatosensory information including texture and shape
Involved in pain processing and modulation
Contributes to sensorimotor integration
Participates in vestibular processing

44.name: Planum Polare (BA 38, 22)
structure: Located on the superior temporal gyrus anterior to Heschl's gyrus
Flat surface on the superior aspect of temporal lobe
Connected to primary auditory cortex and other auditory association areas
Part of the non-primary auditory cortex
function: Involved in processing complex auditory features including melody and timbre
Contributes to voice recognition and emotional prosody
Participates in music perception
Associated with processing of non-verbal auditory stimuli

45.name: Heschl's Gyrus (BA 41, 42)
structure: Primary auditory cortex located on transverse temporal gyrus
Lies deep within lateral sulcus on superior temporal plane
Tonotopically organized with medial-to-lateral high-to-low frequency mapping
Receives direct projections from medial geniculate nucleus of thalamus
function: Initial cortical processing of auditory information
Encodes basic auditory features including frequency, amplitude, and timing
Critical for sound detection and discrimination
Bilateral lesions can result in cortical deafness

46.name: Planum Temporale (BA 22)
structure: Located on the superior surface of the temporal lobe, posterior to Heschl's gyrus
Part of the Wernicke's area in the left hemisphere
Larger in the left hemisphere in most right-handed individuals (structural asymmetry)
Rich in neuronal connections with auditory cortex, inferior parietal lobule, and frontal regions
function: Critical for language comprehension and phonological processing
Involved in auditory processing of complex sounds and speech
Plays a role in music perception and processing of pitch patterns
Left planum temporale damage contributes to receptive language disorders like Wernicke's aphasia

47.name: Supracalcarine Cortex (BA 17/18)
structure: Located superior to the calcarine sulcus in the medial occipital lobe
Primarily represents the inferior visual field in the primary visual cortex
Contains high density of cells in layer IV receiving direct projections from the lateral geniculate nucleus
Has distinctive stria of Gennari (dense band of myelinated fibers in layer IV)
function: Processes visual information from the contralateral lower quadrant of visual field
Performs initial cortical processing of visual features including orientation, spatial frequency, and color
Integrates information from both eyes with ocular dominance columns
Damage results in inferior quadrantanopia in the contralateral visual field

48.name: Occipital Pole (BA 17/18)
structure: Forms the posterior extremity of the occipital lobe
Contains primary visual cortex (V1) and adjacent secondary visual areas
Characterized by thin cortex with prominent layer IV (granular) and stria of Gennari
Receives direct projections from the lateral geniculate nucleus via the optic radiations
function: Processes central (foveal) vision with large cortical representation
Performs initial detection of visual features including edges, orientation, and spatial frequency
Organizes visual input retinotopically with central vision represented posteriorly
Damage results in central scotomas or homonymous hemianopia depending on extent
